description:
Astathelohania contejeani is a species of protozoan parasite that belongs to the phylum Microsporidia. Microsporidia are a group of obligate intracellular parasites that infect a wide range of hosts, including insects, vertebrates, and even other microorganisms.

Astathelohania contejeani is known to infect the freshwater crayfish, Austropotamobius pallipes, which is a species of crayfish found in Europe. The parasite primarily targets the muscle tissues of the crayfish, leading to a condition known as "porcelain disease" or "white tail disease."

The life cycle of A. contejeani involves the production of spores, which are the infectious stage of the parasite. These spores are ingested by the crayfish, and they subsequently invade the host's muscle cells, where they multiply and eventually cause the host's tissues to become discolored and deformed.

The infection by A. contejeani can have significant impacts on the crayfish population, as it can reduce the survival and reproduction of infected individuals. This, in turn, can have broader ecological consequences, as crayfish are important components of freshwater ecosystems.

Understanding the biology and ecology of A. contejeani is important for the conservation and management of crayfish populations, as well as for the development of effective control measures against this parasite.
